Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: The project is still in exploratory discussions, and alternative approaches can be proposed later
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A long-time congregant requested a private meeting soon because of mounting family stress.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread before me, my mind tracing the lines of a new design. The project was still in its early stages, and my manager had emphasized the importance of exploring every possible solution. I knew I should be brainstorming, preparing to present fresh ideas at tomorrow’s meeting. Yet, my phone buzzed with a message from Brother Ahmad, a long-time congregant. He asked if I could meet him tonight—he sounded desperate, his family troubles weighing heavily on him. As an imam, I felt the pull of duty, the expectation to offer comfort and guidance when my community needed me most. But as an engineer, I was expected to be thorough and innovative, to give my full attention to the project’s demands. The two roles pressed in on me, each demanding my time, my focus, my heart. I stared at the phone, then at the blueprints, feeling the tension coil inside me, uncertain which call I should answer first.
